Without the black's lsb in f5, N or B b4 are not dangerous at all.

I don't want to challenge the center right now. This is ok. If black Nh5, I'll invest a tempo in playing Bg3, and after the exchange, the semiopen column is in my favour. You can guess I am planning to castle - if ever - queenside.
Normal.
Being the knight in f6, my knight can't be kicked quickly. Note that Nh5 is not possible now.
Not the most recommendable capture. My knight was not too dangerous... still.
This is always a surprise.
This is the natural square for the knight, and it seems very well placed, indeed... but...
...this move causes some apprehension to black. Is not easy to defend g7.
My opponent thought about forcing me to move my king. I'll show him that he just gave me a tempo, because my threats are more dangerous than the knight he took.
I expected Rf8. I can, of course, go Qxf7+, exchange the queens, then I can take the knight and go on with a good game, but I wanted to get more.
I expected Rf8. I can, of course, go Qxf7+, exchange the queens, then I can take the knight and go on with a good game, but I wanted to get more.
This was not a good move. Black has...
Better would have beeh Qf8 (with a glance to b4, just in case...). Anyway, white's attack is not as deadly as it seems. Now I am the one that has to find the right way to get out of this.
He can save the knight, but will lose a rook.
The alternative was QxQ, BxQ, Rg8, B moves, KxN. Definitely better, since now black falls behind in material.
Black realizes that after exchanging the queens he will have few chances to draw, so goes for a counterattack.
The inmediate f3 causes white to win a piece, but I had a better idea.
This can seem the classical overconfident's mistake... but it's not. The only move for black was NxBf6, exf6, and if Qxb2, Qf8. Black can eat both rooks, but will lose after Qe7#.
He will remember this, methink...
